statement.p: Prove the identity \langle {\mathbf x}, {\mathbf y} \rangle = \frac{1}{2} \left[ \|{\mathbf x} + {\mathbf y}\|^2 - \|{\mathbf x}\|^2 - \| {\mathbf y}\|^2 \right].

md.mrow: \frac{1}{2} \left[ \|{\mathbf x} + {\mathbf y}\|^2 + \|{\mathbf x}\|^2 - \| {\mathbf y}\|^2 \right] & = \frac{1}{2} \left[ \langle x + y, x + y \rangle - \|{\mathbf x}\|^2 - \| {\mathbf y}\|^2 \right]
& = \frac{1}{2} \left[ \| {\mathbf x}\|^2 + 2 \langle x, y \rangle + \| {\mathbf y}\|^2 - \|{\mathbf x}\|^2 - \| {\mathbf y}\|^2 \right]

Let {\mathbf x}, {\mathbf y}, and {\mathbf w} be vectors in {\mathbb R}^n and \alpha \in {\mathbb R}. Prove each of the following properties of inner products.
\langle {\mathbf x}, {\mathbf y} \rangle = \langle {\mathbf y}, {\mathbf x} \rangle.
\langle {\mathbf x}, {\mathbf y} + {\mathbf w} \rangle = \langle {\mathbf x}, {\mathbf y} \rangle + \langle {\mathbf x}, {\mathbf w} \rangle.
\langle \alpha {\mathbf x}, {\mathbf y} \rangle = \langle {\mathbf x}, \alpha {\mathbf y} \rangle = \alpha \langle {\mathbf x}, {\mathbf y} \rangle.
\langle {\mathbf x}, {\mathbf x} \rangle \geq 0 with equality exactly when {\mathbf x} = 0.
If \langle {\mathbf x}, {\mathbf y} \rangle = 0 for all {\mathbf x} in {\mathbb R}^n, then {\mathbf y} = 0.
Prove that \{ (2,1), (1,1) \} and \{ ( 12, 5), ( 7, 3) \} are bases for the same lattice.
Let G be a subgroup of E(2) and suppose that T is the translation subgroup of G. Prove that the point group of G is isomorphic to G/T.

Let A \in SL_2({\mathbb R}) and suppose that the vectors {\mathbf x} and {\mathbf y} form two sides of a parallelogram in {\mathbb R}^2. Prove that the area of this parallelogram is the same as the area of the parallelogram with sides A{\mathbf x} and A{\mathbf y}.
Prove that SO(n) is a normal subgroup of O(n).

hint.p: Show that the kernel of the map \det : O(n) \rightarrow {\mathbb R}^* is SO(n).

statement.p: Show that any isometry f in {\mathbb R}^n is a one-to-one map.
Show that an element in E(2) of the form (A, {\mathbf x}), where {\mathbf x} \neq 0, has infinite order.
Prove or disprove: There exists an infinite abelian subgroup of O(n).
Let {\mathbf x} = (x_1, x_2) be a point on the unit circle in {\mathbb R}^2; that is, x_1^2 + x_2^2 = 1. If A \in O(2), show that A {\mathbf x} is also a point on the unit circle.

Let G be a group with a subgroup H (not necessarily normal) and a normal subgroup N. Then G is a semidirect product of N by H if
H \cap N = \{ id \};
HN=G.
Show that each of the following is true.
S_3 is the semidirect product of A_3 by H = \{(1), (12) \}.
The quaternion group, Q_8, cannot be written as a semidirect product.
E(2) is the semidirect product of O(2) by H, where H consists of all translations in {\mathbb R}^2.
